The key reason for better generalization is the adaptive self-distillation loss. It has been shown inÂ (Mobahi etÂ al., 2020) that self-distillation improves the generalization in centralized settings. It has also been empirically shown inÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2019) that self-distillation helps the model to converge to a flat minimum. Generally, converging to flat minimum is indicative of improved generalization, a concept explored in prior studiesÂ (Keskar etÂ al., 2017; Yao etÂ al., 2020). The top eigenvalue and the trace of the Hessian computed from the training loss are typical measures of â€˜flatnessâ€™ of the minimum to which the training converges, i.e., lower values of these measures indicate the presence of a flat minimum.
To gain a deeper understanding of this phenomenon in a federated learning setting, we analyze the top eigenvalue and the trace of the Hessian of the cross-entropy loss for global models obtained with and without the ASD regularizer. The following argument establishes that if the client models converge to flat minimum, it would also ensure convergence of the resultant global model to a flat minimum.
We assume the Hessians of the functions fksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜f_{k} (ktâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„k^{th} clientâ€™s local objective), fğ‘“f (resultant global objective) exist and are continuous. Since f=1Kâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Kfiğ‘“1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{i=1}^{K}{f_{i}}, we have ğ‡â€‹(f)=1Kâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Kğ‡â€‹(fi)ğ‡ğ‘“1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾ğ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\mathbf{H}(f)=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{i=1}^{K}\mathbf{H}({f_{i}}) (ğ‡â€‹(g)ğ‡ğ‘”\mathbf{H}(g) denotes the Hessian of function gğ‘”g). This implies Î¼1â€‹(ğ‡â€‹(f))â‰¤1Kâ€‹âˆ‘i=1KÎ¼1â€‹(ğ‡â€‹(fi))subscriptğœ‡1ğ‡ğ‘“1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾subscriptğœ‡1ğ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\mu_{1}({\mathbf{H}(f)})\leq\frac{1}{K}{\sum_{i=1}^{K}}\mu_{1}({\mathbf{H}(f_{i})}) (Î¼1â€‹(ğ€)subscriptğœ‡1ğ€\mu_{1}(\mathbf{A}) denotes top eigenvalue of matrix ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}). Thus when the local models converge to a flat minimum, it will ensure the convergence of the global model to a flat minimum.
Following the method ofÂ (Yao etÂ al., 2020), we computed the top eigenvalue and trace of the Hessian. In TableÂ 1, we observe that FedAvg+ASD attains lower values for the top eigenvalue and trace compared to FedAvg, suggesting convergence to flat minimum. The Eigen density plot in the figureÂ 3 also confirms the same. A similar concept has been explored in FedSAMÂ (Qu etÂ al., 2022; Caldarola etÂ al., 2022). But the issue with SAM-based methods is that they require an extra forward and backward pass which doubles the computation cost of the edge devices. However, our method can be applied to SAM-based methods and further improve its performance. ASD consistently attains the flatness with the other FL algorithms and enhances their generalization, these are described in SectionÂ H of the Appendix.

In TableÂ 2, we report the performance of CIFAR-100 and Tiny-ImageNet datasets with various algorithms for non-iid (Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(Î´=0.3)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ›¿0.3Dir(\delta=0.3) and Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(Î´=0.6)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ›¿0.6Dir(\delta=0.6)) and the iid settings. Each experiment is performed over 3 different initializations, and the mean and standard deviation of the accuracy is reported.
The test accuracy vs communication rounds plot on CIFAR-100 dataset is shown in FigureÂ 4. We observe that our proposed ASD applied on FedDyn improves its performance by â‰ˆ1.1%absentpercent1.1\approx 1.1\% for Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(Î´=0.3)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ›¿0.3Dir(\delta=0.3) and â‰ˆ1.6%absentpercent1.6\approx 1.6\% Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(Î´=0.6)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ›¿0.6Dir(\delta=0.6). We can see that adding ASD gives consistent improvement across the rounds222In the figures we only compare FedAvg, FedDyn and FedSpeed for better readability. For others please refer to SecÂ F of the Appendix.
A similar plot for Tiny-Imagenet dataset is shown in FigureÂ 5. We observe that FedDyn+ASD improves FedDyn by â‰ˆ1.4%absentpercent1.4\approx 1.4\% for Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(Î´=0.3)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ›¿0.3Dir(\delta=0.3) and by â‰ˆ2.4%absentpercent2.4\approx 2.4\% for Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(Î´=0.6)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ›¿0.6Dir(\delta=0.6).
We obtain significant improvements for FedAvg+ASD against FedAvg, FedProx+ASD against FedProx, FedSpeed+ASD against FedSpeed, etc. In SecÂ C of the Appendix we present the CIFAR-10 results where we observe that adding ASD consistently gives an improvement of â‰ˆ0.7%âˆ’0.8%absentpercent0.7percent0.8\approx 0.7\%-0.8\% improvement across all the algorithms. Further ablations are provided in SectionÂ E of the Appendix.

We analyze the impact of the proposed adaptive weighting scheme.
We compare by making all the alpha values in EqÂ 10 to 111. We can see from TableÂ 6 that in the non-iid scenarios, the proposed adaptive weighting scheme is better than assigning the uniform weights, thus establishing the impact of proposed adaptive weights.

A8.T7.caption: Table 7: The table shows the impact of ASD on the algorithms on CIFAR-100 Dataset. We consistently see that the top eigenvalue and the trace of the Hessian decrease and the Accuracy improves when ASD is used. This suggests that using ASD makes the global model reach to a flat minimum for better generalization.
